string-array.name: movements_description
string-array.item: a trend in European literature of the early XVI century — late XVIII century, characterized by a combination of religious and secular motifs, images, attraction to different, contrasts, complex metaphors, allegory and emblematic, the desire to impress the reader with lush, colorful style, rhetorical decoration.
a trend in European literature, in the XVII century — early XIX century, which is characterized by a focus on ancient literature, which was proclaimed ideal, classical, worthy of imitation.

a trend in European literature of the second half of the 18th and the beginning of the 19th centuries, which is characterized by the desire to recreate the world of ordinary people's feelings and evoke the reader's sympathy for the heroes of the work.

a trend in European literature and art of the late XVIII — early XIX centuries., Whose representatives fought against the canons of classicism, brought to the fore the interests of the individual and feelings and used in their work historical and folk poetry.
a literary trend that is characterized by a true and comprehensive reflection of reality based on the typification of life phenomena.
a total term denoting a set of literary trends and schools of the XX century, which are characterized by creativity, experimentation, attraction to conventional means, anti-realist orientation.
a literary trend marked by feelings of hopelessness, frustration, loss of vitality, and aestheticism.

the conditional name of aesthetic tendencies that emerged in world culture, in particular in literature, painting and music, which is traditionally associated with modernist reactions to positivism and naturalism in the late XIX — early XX centuries.
an artistic direction based on the principle of direct fixation of impressions, observations, empathy.
a literary and artistic stylistic trend of avant-garde that emerged in Germany in the early twentieth century.
a literary trend of the late XIX - early XX centuries, the main feature of which is that a particular artistic image becomes a multifaceted symbol.

a trend in literature, which found expression in the use of ancient themes and plots, mythological images and motifs, the proclamation of the slogans of "pure" art and worship devoid of social meaning art form, in glorifying earthly pleasures that emerged in Western European literature in the mid-nineteenth century.

a literary trend that emerged in the early twentieth century in Italy, which is characterized by images of large industrial cities, their atmosphere and way of life; the cult of the superman who rules the world through scientific advances.

a stylistic trend in Ukrainian literature and world literature of the early twentieth century, which is also called socio-psychological, romantic, impressionistic or lyrical-psychological realism, which developed from classical realism.
a trend in twentieth-century philosophy that positions and explores man as a unique spiritual being capable of choosing his own destiny.

a literary movement that emerged in the United States and Europe in the late twentieth century, the aesthetic nature of which is associated with pluralism - the concept of having many different views, positions, ideas and interests at the same time.
